sn44.7:1.1: See SN 33.1:1.2 and note for Vacchagotta. | This discourse introduces the full set of ten undeclared points.
sn44.7:2.1: Loka originally meant “light”, hence the sky bright with gods (stars), from which developed the meanings “heaven”, a “world”, and the “cosmos”. Sometimes Vedists believed that an “eternal world” was won by those worthy (DN 1:1.31.5). However, the Suttas often discuss the Upaniṣadic notion that the “self and the cosmos are eternal” (DN 1:1.30.1, MN 102:14.2), where loka means the “cosmos” as a whole, not a specific heavenly “world”. But the distinction is not always clear-cut. See also next note.
sn44.7:2.7: The distinction between a limited “world” and an infinite “cosmos” was said to depend on the wisdom and spiritual depth of the individual: “Those who venerate (water, breath, and moon) as finite win only a limited world, whereas those who venerate them as infinite win a world without limit” (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.5.13, Olivelle translation).
sn44.7:2.13: The term “soul” (jīva) was favored by the samaṇas, as opposed to the “self” (attā) of the brahmins. Both are rejected by the Buddha as forms of “metaphysical” self: they postulate the absolute, eternal existence of entities that cannot be established empirically. The repeated demonstrative pronouns (taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīraṁ) assert an emphatic identity.
